ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Question 8: Chad Oliver is great! I am most impressed with how he explains concepts using pictures he took himself (mostly.

Yale F&ES is a good place to put it all together: how are we feeding, clothing, housing people, and affording ourselves places for recreation and refreshment? How is biodiversity affected by us? What are we doing to the climate? What is happening to ecosystem services because of us? How many people are there, and what is human population doing -- expanding? shrinking? One will get out of the course what one puts in. I recommend taking it, keeping up with the reading, participating in class, starting the data mining exercise early. Chad Oliver is very knowledgeable (an understatement) as well as very supportive of each and every student. The main material for the course is a book Chad is co-writing. It is interesting to see how Chad and Fatma are putting together global statistics and projections; and one has an opportunity to speak ideas that could be included in what will be a very important text for the educated -- or wanting-to-be-educated --- layperson.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The data mining project.
Chad class session was excellent. data mining exercise was also extremely useful.
The Japanese style presentation and the Data mining exercise. It was a useful skill (Data mining exercise) that will help me in other classes and professionally
The data mining project. Discussions in class. Chad's welcoming and supportive demeanor.

The personal experience that the professor brings to the class is excellent. He has a global view of all the issue discussed in class. The diversity in the class both in career focus and countries of origin was really important and gave broad insights to the contents of the class.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Overall was good.
i was comfortable with how the class was taught

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Students should get more involved in discussion, instead of the class feeling like a lecture.
He took his time to explain concepts and in cases where something was not clear, he would send out emails to the class providing further explanation and other materials.
Good. Discussions in class were frequent and integral to the course.
The relationship was excellent.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Absolutely fit into my goal here in Yale.

I am interested in Agriculture and rural development and the course touched on this. There was a full section dedicated to Agriculture. Moreover, i could see and appreciate the relevance of the other section in relation to my interest. I learnt some new information which will help shape my understanding of the environment in general, going forward.
The course fits well. I came to Yale wanting to understand the big picture of global processes.
My focus is in water Resources.this class touched on water and other interlinked aspects including but not limited to Forests, Agriculture and Government organisation.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Improve and learn more on all issues on managing resources.
Because of the range of topic listed in the syllabus. I was curious to find out what the content will and i ended up staying in the class.
As indicated elsewhere: I came to Yale wanting to understand the big picture of global processes.
It aligned perfectly with my Water Resources focus.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
Yes.

Yes it did meet my expectation. It helped clarify some wrong assumption i had about the environment and climate change. It also helped to explain some phenomena I am familiar with but never understood.
Yes.
It met my expectations and also opened up new interests in Forest management.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: We worked together to answer sample questions for final exam.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Yes

It has a very broad scope, so if you're trying to figure out what topics might interest you, then it's good for that. On the other hand, if you've taken a lot of environmental studies classes in the past it might be repetitive.

Take it, if you want to learn contemporary issues on managing resources and some thoughtful ideas on managing resources by the instructor. most of the class materials are based on Chad book draft on managing resources.

This course is amazing but the name at first will give you a wrong assumption. The name sound broad, yes, but the content is amazing and detailed and can be as specific as you want. Especially during class discussions. You should take this course if you want to know about the environment and its resources in one sitting.

Take it if you will do the reading, participate in class, be enthusiastic about the wonderful data mining project. I believe everyone in our class did these things, and so we had a fantastic class -- the people and the process.
if your looking for a class that is focused on data mining and its use and covers a wide range of natural resources, this will be a good class to take
